results.title: The Dissenter
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Renaissance”.
This program documents the lives and ideas of dissenters who suffered death and/or excommunication in their challenge to the power of the Church. Through dramatic re-enactments you meet Jan Hus, John Wyclif, Martin Luther, Argula Von Grumbach, and others who questioned established authority. The essence of dissent is captured through interviews with modern day dissenters fighting orthodoxy.

results.title: Cognitive processes
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Why have people always been able to link different elements and ideas into coherent relationships? It is our thoughts, our cognitive processes, that give meaning to everything. In this program, Philip Zimbardo examines the work of cognitive psychologists who study how people take in information, store it, transmit it and manipulate it, that is, exploring how we think and solve problems.

results.title: Language development
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How do we learn to speak? Are we born with some innate ability to speak or do we learn by imitating our parents? This program looks at the stages a young child goes through in learning to speak and the roles that nature and nurture play in the process. We look at how parents unconsciously adapt their normal speech patterns when speaking to very young children, at recent research into biological maturation of the brain and facial muscles, and at the social situations which also contribute to this unique ability of the human species to communicate through speech.

results.title: The responsive brain
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
The relationship between brain and behaviour is reciprocal. Although our behaviour is influenced by the brain, the brain can also be changed, quite literally, by behaviour. Philip Zimbardo takes, as examples of this change, the need for touch in infants, the lack of which can lead to impaired physical and mental development, and the effects of stress on our ability to learn and to grow.
results.description:

results.title: Understanding research
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
What methods do psychologists use to probe human nature? In this program, Philip Zimbardo explains the methods of scientific research including the principles of laboratory experiments, surveys, interviews and psychological tests. In doing so, he considers the validity of lie detector tests, questions the reality of psychic powers and outlines the power of the “placebo” effect when a patient’s condition improves simply because they believe their treatment is doing them good.
results.description:

results.title: The Divine Garbo
results.creator_credit: Susan F Walker, Ellen Krass and Turner Pictures
results.brief_description: Garbo - the undefinable mystique. The most elusive, seductive and enigmatic actress the cinema has ever known, this Swedish star attracted audiences like no other. Her intense desire for privacy became legendary, vanishing from the screen - and the public - at the height of her commercial success. Hosted by actress Glenn Close, this video presents an insight to the mysterious Greta Garbo, including clips from such films as “Grand Hotel”, “Queen Christina”, “Anna Karenina”, “Camille” and “Ninotchka”, plus some rare behind-the-scenes glimpses, screen-test footage and foreign film clips - all of which only add to enhance the legend of one of Hollywood’s most elusive screen love goddesses.

results.title: The Discovery of insulin
results.creator_credit: Stanley Jackson, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Here is the inspiring story of how, in July, 1921, in a little-used laboratory at the University of Toronto, two young Canadians, Frederick Banting and Charles Best, discovered insulin. Their work gave the hope of life and health to the world’s millions of diabetics. (An abridged version of The Quest)

results.title: Sky's Adventure [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Willow McFadzean, Parker Arnel and Hurstbridge Primary School
results.brief_description: ‘Sky’s Adventure’ is about a girl Sky and a mean girl Britney. Britney was never nice to anyone but she has to reflect on that when Sky says something to her. Will Britney change after reflecting on what she’s done or keep doing it?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Willow McFadzean, Parker Arnel and Hurstbridge Primary School

results.title: Transition
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Jordan, Sannah Maclean and Presbyterian Ladies' College
results.brief_description: Reflecting on the past can sometimes help you make sense of the present. An elderly man contemplates his life alone when the family are gone.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rebecca Jordan, Sannah Maclean and Presbyterian Ladies’ College

results.title: Time Machine [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Werner van Niekerk, Cameron Cockrell and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description: ‘Time Machine’ is about robots that take over the world but there is a scientist that builds a robot that will take back the world. So it is your job to get past the boss. When you get past the boss you get a high score and the minions will try to kill you so watch out and have fun. There are bouncing pads that can help you jump higher and get things like health and score and save you too. There is also health which goes down when you are hit by evil robots or fireballs. Health packs increase your health.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Werner van Niekerk, Cameron Cockrell and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
